commit_message:
DNM: Separate mapping vs no-mapping code paths

The referenced story speculates that performance degradation since
introduction of microversion 1.34 (mappings in allocation candidate
results) [1] may be due to (a) increased object hashing cost and/or (b)
the new data processing in the output.

This commit separates the pre- and post-mapping data handling
completely, which should eliminate (b) for microversions prior to 1.34.

If the performance goes back to previous levels, (a) is not to blame,
and we may wish to merge (some variant of) this patch.

If the performance is unaffected, (a) is the culprit and should be
investigated further.

If somewhere in the middle, we may wish to merge (some variant of) this
patch as well as investigating (a).

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662245

Change-Id: I45a6f73b17dbbce8fde931e90ab2cbea3e8bfcad
Story: #2005889
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/placement refs/changes/48/665448/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _no_mappings(): for ar in alloc_reqs: # A default dict of {$rp_uuid: "resources": {}) rp_resources = collections.defaultdict(lambda: dict(resources={})) for rr in ar.resource_requests: res_dict = rp_resources[rr.resource_provider.uuid]['resources'] res_dict[rr.resource_class] = rr.amount results.append(dict(allocations=rp_resources)) def _with_mappings(): for ar in alloc_reqs: # A default dict of {$rp_uuid: "resources": {}) rp_resources = collections.defaultdict(lambda: dict(resources={})) # A dict to map request group suffixes to the providers that # provided solutions to that group. mappings = collections.defaultdict(list) for rr in ar.resource_requests: suffix = rr.suffix mappings[suffix].append(rr.resource_provider.uuid) res_dict = rp_resources[rr.resource_provider.uuid]['resources'] res_dict[rr.resource_class] = rr.amount results.append(dict(allocations=rp_resources, mappings=mappings)) if want_version.matches((1, 34)): _with_mappings() else: _no_mappings()
deleted_lines: for ar in alloc_reqs: # A default dict of {$rp_uuid: "resources": {}) rp_resources = collections.defaultdict(lambda: dict(resources={})) # A dict to map request group suffixes to the providers that provided # solutions to that group. mappings = collections.defaultdict(list) for rr in ar.resource_requests: suffix = rr.suffix mappings[suffix].append(rr.resource_provider.uuid) res_dict = rp_resources[rr.resource_provider.uuid]['resources'] res_dict[rr.resource_class] = rr.amount result = dict(allocations=rp_resources) if want_version.matches((1, 34)): result['mappings'] = mappings results.append(result)

subject: DNM: sparse parent dict breaks _check_same_subtree
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-08-14 17:35:41.000000000', 'files': ['placement/objects/allocation_candidate.py', 'placement/tests/unit/objects/test_allocation_candidate.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/placement/commit/7c2d2b455495cc6d60feae9e292ce94e9373e5b5', 'message': 'DNM: sparse parent dict breaks _check_same_subtree

Following the discussion at [1], this patch exercises
_check_same_subtree with a parent_uuid_by_rp_uuid dict that only
includes providers involved in the request. In order to make this work,
the delta at [1] is put into place: this makes the recursion to discover
a provider's ancestry line stop as soon as it hits a provider not
involved in the request.

This causes one scenario [2] to fail: where there's a "hole" in the
ancestry chain for one of the providers, ancestors on the other side of
that hole are not counted in the ancestry line, so same_subtree can
return False when it should have been True.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/675606/2/placement/objects/allocation_candidate.py@908
[2] I checked by commenting out that scenario - the rest pass

Change-Id: I077eef58a3e89fb402a6cdcb10e4f5688aed3f07
'}]
commit_message:
DNM: sparse parent dict breaks _check_same_subtree

Following the discussion at [1], this patch exercises
_check_same_subtree with a parent_uuid_by_rp_uuid dict that only
includes providers involved in the request. In order to make this work,
the delta at [1] is put into place: this makes the recursion to discover
a provider's ancestry line stop as soon as it hits a provider not
involved in the request.

This causes one scenario [2] to fail: where there's a "hole" in the
ancestry chain for one of the providers, ancestors on the other side of
that hole are not counted in the ancestry line, so same_subtree can
return False when it should have been True.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/675606/2/placement/objects/allocation_candidate.py@908
[2] I checked by commenting out that scenario - the rest pass

Change-Id: I077eef58a3e89fb402a6cdcb10e4f5688aed3f07
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/placement refs/changes/71/676471/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This fails with sparse parent_by_rp because 020's ancestry line # stops at 02 and therefore doesn't include 0. # Winnow parent_by_rp to only include the providers involved in the # request sparse_parent_by_rp = { k: v for k, v in parent_by_rp.items() if k in group} self.assertTrue( ac_obj._check_same_subtree(group, sparse_parent_by_rp), (group, sparse_parent_by_rp)) # Winnow parent_by_rp to only include the providers involved in the # request sparse_parent_by_rp = { k: v for k, v in parent_by_rp.items() if k in group} self.assertFalse( ac_obj._check_same_subtree(group, sparse_parent_by_rp))

commit_message:
DNM: sparse parent dict breaks same_subtree (part deux)

Following the discussion at [1], this patch exercises same_subtree with
a parent_uuid_by_rp_uuid dict that only includes providers involved in
the request. In order to make this work, the delta at [1] is put into
place: this makes the recursion to discover a provider's ancestry line
stop as soon as it hits a provider not involved in the request.

This breaks a gabbi test written previously [2] to demonstrate the
problem: when there's a "hole" in the ancestry chain for one of the
providers, ancestors on the other side of that hole are not counted in
the ancestry line, so same_subtree can return False when it should have
been True.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/675606/2/placement/objects/allocation_candidate.py@908
[2] I5062e725d6f29cd997b974a0dad7dc4d0ed2900f

Change-Id: Ib498fe29ecb7cefd49cf153de328061c09ef9061
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/placement refs/changes/77/676477/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
WIP: Microversion 1.37: Adds support for consumer_types

Switched to a test and spec driven approach via a
consumer-types-1.37.yaml gabbit. That identified some issues
which are starting to be addressed, but still plenty more to do.

Reshaper now works. Now this needs to be split up and cleaned up.

Change-Id: I441422078609a14c37d9ded7b0741161297dd2ce

Release notes cleanup for 13.0.0

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/85/679985/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Adds the missing ``ipxe`` boot interface to the ``iRMC`` hardware type. It is supposed to be used instead of the deprecated ``ipxe_enabled`` configuration option.
deleted_lines: upgrade: - | iRMC hardware type deals with iPXE boot interface incompatibility. To iPXE boot with ``ipxe`` boot interface, *(1)* add ``ipxe`` to ``enabled_boot_interfaces`` in ``ironic.conf``, *(2)* set up tftp & http server following `Ironic document on iPXE boot configuration <https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configure-pxe.html>`, then *(3)* create/set baremetal node with ``--boot-interface ipxe``. iRMC hardware type deals with iPXE boot interface incompatibility. From Stein, ``[pxe]ipxe_enabled`` option has been deprecated and will be removed in preference to ``ipxe`` boot interface in Train cycle. Till then, iRMC hardware type supports iPXE boot through ``[pxe]ipxe_enabled`` option. To cope with this incompatibility, iRMC hardware type supports ``ipxe`` boot interface.

Update docs to refer to PROJECT instead of TENANT

Updates several references for things like OS_TENANT_NAME and
--os-tenant-name.

commit_message:
Drop support for OS_TENANT_NAME and OS_TENANT_ID

These have been deprecated for a very long time now. Switch to only
support the current OS_PROJECT_NAME and OS_PROJECT_ID.

Change-Id: I2fb78768b4308a3aaf12764edadb58d4a307adaa
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Fix timeout Zuul changes

Change I90cbfdaad582900f3047acffbfcdd3189335ffbf added a timeout for
lower-constraints only to check queue but missed gate, add it there.

Change I0b9e0fbbd1760fe2d55935592f4349f337801209 added tox-cover to gate
but it is never run in gate, see
https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/zuul.d/project-templates.yaml#L416
Remove it again.

Change-Id: I78eaa450cdb7a84d9a81e2354a97617681babc40

commit_message:
Update default CRUSH algorithm to straw2

straw2 has been the default CRUSH algorithm since hammer
and Ubuntu Xenial ships with Jewel, meaning that straw2
is the default in all current LTS releases.

Change-Id: I6fa4072eb33d763aca5721ee9fdd30b60d468a44
Closes-Bug: #1836092

commit_message:
Unbreak CI: fluentd

fluentd - we are not deploying kubernetes, no need for plugins

In the original commit we also dropped Tripleo from the gate, but in
Rocky the Tripleo job did not exist.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/37/681437/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This example shows you how to create and access a MySQL 5.7 database. parameters: - A volume size of ``5`` (5 GB) - A database named ``test`` ``5.7`` datastore version - A Neutron network ``8799cf10-01ef-40e2-b04e-06da7cfa5668`` to allocate the database IP address (for internal access). - Expose the instance to the public via ``--is-public`` (for external access). Ignore this parameter if you don't want to expose database service to the public internet. - Only the IP addresses coming from ``202.37.199.1/24`` or ``10.1.0.1/24`` are allowed to access the database service. $ openstack database instance create mysql_instance_1 \ 6 \ --size 5 \ --nic net-id=8799cf10-01ef-40e2-b04e-06da7cfa5668 \ --databases test --users userA:password \ --datastore mysql --datastore_version 5.7 \ --is-public \ --allowed-cidr 10.1.0.1/24 \ --allowed-cidr 202.37.199.1/24 +-------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +-------------------+--------------------------------------+ | created | 2019-09-11T09:19:18 | | datastore | mysql | | datastore_version | 5.7 | | flavor | 6 | | id | 4bca2f27-f986-419e-ab4a-df1db399d590 | | name | mysql_instance_1 | | region | RegionOne | | status | BUILD | | updated | 2019-09-11T09:19:18 | | volume | 5 | +-------------------+--------------------------------------+ Both internal and external IP addresses can be shown by running: $ openstack database instance show 4bca2f27-f986-419e-ab4a-df1db399d590 | Field | Value | | created | 2019-09-11T07:14:37 | | datastore | mysql | | datastore_version | 5.7 | | flavor | 6 | | id | 4bca2f27-f986-419e-ab4a-df1db399d590 | | ip | 10.1.0.14, 172.24.5.15 | | name | mysql_instance_1 | | region | RegionOne | | status | ACTIVE | | updated | 2019-09-11T07:14:47 | | volume | 5 | | volume_used | 0.12 | You can now access the new database you just created by using ``IP_ADDRESS`` with either 10.1.0.14 or 172.24.5.15 according to where the command is running. Make sure your IP address is in the allowed CIDRs specified in the above command. $ mysql -h IP_ADDRESS -uuserA -ppassword
deleted_lines: This example shows you how to create and access a MySQL 5.5 database. characteristics: In addition, this command specifies these options for the instance: - A volume size of ``5`` (5 GB). - The ``myDB`` database. ``mysql-5.5`` datastore\_version. $ openstack database instance create mysql_instance_1 6 --size 5 --databases myDB \ --users userA:password --datastore_version mysql-5.5 \ --datastore mysql +-------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------t-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | Property | Value | +-------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | created | 2014-05-29T21:26:21 | | datastore | {u'version': u'mysql-5.5', u'type': u'mysql'} | | datastore_version | mysql-5.5 | | flavor | {u'id': u'6', u'links': [{u'href': u'https://controller:8779/v1.0/46d0bc4fc32e4b9e8520f8fc62199f58/flavors/6', u'rel': u'self'}, {u'href': u'https://controller:8779/flavors/6', u'rel': u'bookmark'}]} | | id | 5599dad6-731e-44df-bb60-488da3da9cfe | | name | mysql_instance_1 | | status | BUILD | | updated | 2014-05-29T21:26:21 | | volume | {u'size': 5} | +-------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ First, use the :command:`openstack database instance list` command to list all instances and their IDs: $ openstack database instance list +--------------------------------------+------------------+-----------+-------------------+--------+-----------+------+ | id | name | datastore | datastore_version | status | flavor_id | size | +--------------------------------------+------------------+-----------+-------------------+--------+-----------+------+ | 5599dad6-731e-44df-bb60-488da3da9cfe | mysql_instance_1 | mysql | mysql-5.5 | BUILD | 6 | 5 | +--------------------------------------+------------------+-----------+-------------------+--------+-----------+------+ This command returns the instance ID of your new instance. You can now pass in the instance ID with the :command:`openstack database instance show` command to get the IP address of the instance. In this example, replace ``INSTANCE_ID`` with ``5599dad6-731e-44df-bb60-488da3da9cfe``. .. code-block:: console $ openstack database instance show INSTANCE_ID | Property | Value | | created | 2014-05-29T21:26:21 | | datastore | mysql | | datastore_version | mysql-5.5 | | flavor | 6 | | id | 5599dad6-731e-44df-bb60-488da3da9cfe | | ip | 172.16.200.2 | | name | mysql_instance_1 | | status | BUILD | | updated | 2014-05-29T21:26:54 | | volume | 5 | This command returns the IP address of the database instance. You can now access the new database you just created (myDB) by using ``IP_ADDRESS`` with ``172.16.200.2``. $ mysql -u userA -p password -h IP_ADDRESS myDB

subject: fixup! Add support for translating CPU policy extra specs, image meta
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-09-11 11:08:41.000000000', 'files': ['nova/conf/compute.py', 'nova/scheduler/manager.py', 'nova/scheduler/utils.py', 'nova/tests/functional/libvirt/base.py', 'nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test_utils.py', 'nova/conf/scheduler.py', 'nova/tests/functional/libvirt/test_numa_servers.py', 'releasenotes/notes/cpu-resources-d4e6a0c12681fa87.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c6c56d9c9472648644da74a96e4c41f5ab5b8966', 'message': 'fixup! Add support for translating CPU policy extra specs, image meta

Change-Id: I3a76ca526c91e8eca08f996087108f80b66f1c2e
'}]
commit_message:
fixup! Add support for translating CPU policy extra specs, image meta

Change-Id: I3a76ca526c91e8eca08f996087108f80b66f1c2e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/45/681445/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: configured using the ``[compute] cpu_dedicated_set`` config option. The scheduler will automatically translate the legacy ``hw:cpu_policy`` flavor extra spec or ``hw_cpu_policy`` image metadata property to ``PCPU`` requests, falling back to ``VCPU`` requests only if no ``PCPU`` candidates are found. Refer to the help text of the ``[compute] cpu_dedicated_set``, ``[compute] cpu_shared_set`` and ``vcpu_pin_set`` config options for more information. ``HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING`` trait if the host has hyperthreading. The scheduler will automatically translate the legacy ``hw:cpu_thread_policy`` flavor extra spec or ``hw_cpu_thread_policy`` image metadata property to either require or forbid this trait.
deleted_lines: configured using the ``[compute] cpu_dedicated_set`` config option. Once the compute nodes have been configured, the scheduler should be configured to translate the legacy ``hw:cpu_policy`` flavor extra spec or ``hw_cpu_policy`` image metadata property to ``PCPU`` requests using the ``[scheduler] enable_pinning_policy_translation`` config option. Refer to the help text of the ``[compute] cpu_dedicated_set``, ``[compute] cpu_shared_set``, ``vcpu_pin_set`` and ``[scheduler] enable_pinning_policy_translation`` config options for more information. ``HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING`` trait if the host has hyperthreading. When the scheduler has been configured with ``[scheduler] enable_pinning_policy_translation = True``, the legacy ``hw:cpu_thread_policy`` flavor extra spec or ``hw_cpu_thread_policy`` image metadata property will be translated to either require or forbid this trait. - | A new configuration option, ``[scheduler] enable_pinning_policy_translation``, has been added. When enabled, this will translate the legacy ``hw:cpu_policy`` and ``hw:cpu_thread_policy`` extra specs and their image metadata property equivalents to placement equivalents.

In some deploy production, using volume based instead of localdisk
to protect data and live migrate can perform.

This patch adds:
 - creation a cinder volume for amphora
 - boot amphora with cinder volume
 - config options for cinder client
 - unit tests for cinder functionality

commit_message:
Support create amphora instance from volume based.

In some deploy production, using volume based instead of localdisk
to protect data and live migrate can perform.

This patch adds:
 - creation a cinder volume for amphora
 - boot amphora with cinder volume
 - config options for cinder client
 - unit tests for cinder functionality

Story: 2001594
Co-authored-by: Vadim Ponomarev <velizarx@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Margarita Shakhova <shakhova.margarita@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I8181ed696b9ab556e7741c08839d79167aff8350

commit_message:
Update setup.cfg to include project_urls

The content is based on what pbr does [1] and packaging docs [2].
The links chosen and the names used are whatever we like.

project_urls are used when displaying packages on pypi, the links
show up in the left sidebar under a project links section.
pbr's example [3].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/pbr/latest/user/using.html#setup-cfg
[2] https://packaging.python.org/guides/distributing-packages-using-setuptools/#project-urls
[3] https://pypi.org/project/pbr/

Change-Id: I0c8663b1ed495f141350fd023c78a6ff38bca29f
Story: 2005170
Task: 30915
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/placement refs/changes/39/681239/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: project_urls = Bug Tracker = https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/project/openstack/placement Documentation = https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/ API Reference = https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/placement/ Source Code = https://opendev.org/openstack/placement Release Notes = https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/placement/

subject: Apply SEV-specific guest config when SEV is required
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-03-19 13:14:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/471844e20942bdc9ea525098a71036467ae0261c', 'message': '[wip] Driver changes for sev

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2019-05-31 19:37:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/786e72d7eab10ed6046aa6a94a18a050eff1fd95', 'message': "Detect that SEV is required and enable iommu for devices

Change-Id: Ie54fca066f3333d1d5d18a2c0e8f6c7d5042490b
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2019-06-12 11:34:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/9465fb29a8e173c7f50d5062c5fdd0ba975c1e5d', 'message': 'WIP: Detect that SEV is required and enable iommu for devices

This is still WIP - the _sev_required check needs to be changed to
return true iff:

  a) the supports_amd_sev instance variable in the driver is
     true, *and*

  b) the allocations fed to spawn() show that one slot of
     the MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT resource inventory has been
     allocated to the guest.

When MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT is included in the inventory allocations
for the instance, and the host is capable of SEV, we know that SEV
functionality is required, so the guest config needs to be tweaked
accordingly in various ways.  This change implements the first of
those tweaks, which is to set all virtio devices' "iommu" attributes
to "on".  Subsequent commits will add the other tweaks.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: Ie54fca066f3333d1d5d18a2c0e8f6c7d5042490b
'}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2019-06-17 18:14:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2ca39ccb0ff0a6ac3279e2fc5dcef250ce75ae84', 'message': 'Detect that SEV is required and enable iommu for devices

Add a new _sev_required() method to the libvirt driver to detect that
SEV is required and return True iff the following are both true:

  a) the supports_amd_sev instance variable in the driver is
     true, *and*

  b) the instance extra specs and/or image properties request
     memory encryption to be enabled.

In this case we know that SEV functionality is required, so tweak the
guest config accordingly in various ways.  This change implements the
first of those tweaks, which is to set all virtio devices' "iommu"
attributes to "on".  Subsequent commits will add the other tweaks.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: Ie54fca066f3333d1d5d18a2c0e8f6c7d5042490b
'}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2019-06-18 01:03:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/296f495695961f5a64c1df2a3f5d851dd2591822', 'message': 'Detect that SEV is required and enable iommu for devices

  b) the instance extra specs and/or image properties request
     memory encryption to be enabled.

In this case we know that SEV functionality is required, so tweak the
guest config accordingly in various ways.  This change implements the
first of those tweaks, which is to set all virtio devices' "iommu"
attributes to "on".  Subsequent commits will add the other tweaks.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: Ie54fca066f3333d1d5d18a2c0e8f6c7d5042490b

'}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2019-06-20 20:39:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/89926ac5affc76adec2431f5de7ab1ebfa5abf2e', 'message': 'Apply SEV-specific guest config when SEV is required

Add a new _sev_required() method to the libvirt driver to detect that
SEV is required and return True iff the following are both true:

  a) the supports_amd_sev instance variable in the driver is
     true, *and*

  b) the instance extra specs and/or image properties request
     memory encryption to be enabled.

In this case we know that SEV functionality is required, so tweak the
guest config accordingly in various ways:

- Set all virtio devices' "iommu" attributes to "on".

- Add the <launchSecurity> element to enable use of SEV.  Two related
  configuration values are extracted from domain capabilities and set
  on the element.

- Enable memory locking.  All the memory pages allocated by QEMU must
  be pinned for SEV, which is achieved via <memoryBacking> and <locked />
  elements.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: Ie54fca066f3333d1d5d18a2c0e8f6c7d5042490b

'}, {'number': 26, 'created': '2019-07-27 21:10:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/fb49267a0242798777519bb2bdba9be1150b38fe', 'message': 'Apply SEV-specific guest config when SEV is required

Add a new sev_enabled() function to the libvirt utils to detect that
SEV is required and return True if and only if the following are both
true:

  a) the supports_amd_sev instance variable in the host is
     true, *and*

  b) the instance extra specs and/or image properties request
     memory encryption to be enabled.

In this case we know that SEV functionality is required, so tweak the
guest config accordingly in various ways:

- Ensure that the machine type is some q35 variant.  If the image had
  an hw_machine_type property requesting some other type, this will be
  overridden with a warning.  In order to distinguish between machine
  types requested via hw_machine_type vs. defaults from nova.conf or
  those hardcoded into nova itself, a new get_machine_type_no_default()
  function is introduced to nova.virt.libvirt.utils, together with
  accompanying tests.

- Set all virtio devices' "iommu" attributes to "on".

- Add the <launchSecurity> element to enable use of SEV.  Two related
  configuration values are extracted from domain capabilities and set
  on the element.

- Enable memory locking.  All the memory pages allocated by QEMU must
  be pinned for SEV, which is achieved via <memoryBacking> and <locked />
  elements.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: Ie54fca066f3333d1d5d18a2c0e8f6c7d5042490b
'}, {'number': 27, 'created': '2019-07-27 21:27:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f185d0b66be13fad6dc68c9103c2beb2895be36e', 'message': 'Apply SEV-specific guest config when SEV is required

- Add the <launchSecurity> element to enable use of SEV.  Two related
  configuration values are extracted from domain capabilities and set
  on the element.

- Enable memory locking.  All the memory pages allocated by QEMU must
  be pinned for SEV, which is achieved via <memoryBacking> and <locked />
  elements.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: Ie54fca066f3333d1d5d18a2c0e8f6c7d5042490b
'}, {'number': 32, 'created': '2019-08-08 16:47:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/32e98b30df19f99cddf261155c339268640373e2', 'message': 'Apply SEV-specific guest config when SEV is required

Add a new sev_enabled() function to the libvirt utils to detect that
SEV is required and return True if and only if the following are both
true:

  a) the supports_amd_sev instance variable in the host is
     true, *and*

  b) the instance extra specs and/or image properties request
     memory encryption to be enabled.

In this case we know that SEV functionality is required, so tweak the
guest config accordingly in various ways:

- Ensure that the machine type is some q35 variant.  If the image had
  an hw_machine_type property requesting some other type, this will be
  overridden with a warning.  In order to distinguish between machine
  types requested via hw_machine_type vs. defaults from nova.conf or
  those hardcoded into nova itself, a new get_machine_type_no_default()
  function is introduced to nova.virt.libvirt.utils, together with
  accompanying tests.

- Set all virtio devices' "iommu" attributes to "on".

- Add the <launchSecurity> element to enable use of SEV.  Two related
  configuration values are extracted from domain capabilities and set
  on the element.

- Enable memory locking.  All the memory pages allocated by QEMU must
  be pinned for SEV, which is achieved via <memoryBacking> and <locked />
  elements.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: Ie54fca066f3333d1d5d18a2c0e8f6c7d5042490b

Add a new sev_enabled() function to the libvirt utils to detect that
SEV is required and return True if and only if the following are both
true:

  a) the supports_amd_sev instance variable in the host is
     true, *and*

  b) the instance extra specs and/or image properties request
     memory encryption to be enabled.

In this case we know that SEV functionality is required, so tweak the
guest config accordingly in various ways:

- Ensure that the machine type is some q35 variant.  If the image had
  an hw_machine_type property requesting some other type, this will be
  overridden with a warning.  In order to distinguish between machine
  types requested via hw_machine_type vs. defaults from nova.conf or
  those hardcoded into nova itself, a new get_machine_type_no_default()
  function is introduced to nova.virt.libvirt.utils, together with
  accompanying tests.

- Set all virtio devices' "iommu" attributes to "on".  This is
  achieved by adding another check_set_sev() function which wraps
  around sev_enabled().

- Add the <launchSecurity> element to enable use of SEV.  Two related
  configuration values are extracted from domain capabilities and set
  on the element.

- Enable memory locking.  All the memory pages allocated by QEMU must
  be pinned for SEV, which is achieved via <memoryBacking> and <locked />
  elements.

commit_message:
Apply SEV-specific guest config when SEV is required

Add a new sev_enabled() function to the libvirt utils to detect that
SEV is required and return True if and only if the following are both
true:

  a) the supports_amd_sev instance variable in the host is
     true, *and*

  b) the instance extra specs and/or image properties request
     memory encryption to be enabled.

In this case we know that SEV functionality is required, so tweak the
guest config accordingly in various ways:

- Ensure that the machine type is some q35 variant.  If the image had
  an hw_machine_type property requesting some other type, an
  InvalidMachineType exception will be raised.

- Set the "iommu" attribute to "on" for all relevant devices including
  disk / network devices, but excluding input/graphics/video/serial
  devices.  This is achieved via a new set_driver_iommu_for_sev()
  method added to nova.virt.libvirt.designer.  In order to test this
  thoroughly, beef up the fake KVM guest fixture with extra devices
  of each type.

- Add the <launchSecurity> element to enable use of SEV.  Two related
  configuration values are extracted from domain capabilities and set
  on the element.

- Enable memory locking.  All the memory pages allocated by QEMU must
  be pinned for SEV, which is achieved via <memoryBacking> and <locked />
  elements.

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: Ie54fca066f3333d1d5d18a2c0e8f6c7d5042490b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/65/644565/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(host.Host, 'get_domain_capabilities') def test_get_guest_config_sev(self, fake_domain_caps): sev_feature = vconfig.LibvirtConfigDomainCapsFeatureSev() sev_feature.cbitpos = 47 sev_feature.reduced_phys_bits = 1 domain_caps = vconfig.LibvirtConfigDomainCaps() domain_caps._features = vconfig.LibvirtConfigDomainCapsFeatures() domain_caps._features.features = [sev_feature] fake_domain_caps.return_value = domain_caps drvr = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), True) test_instance = copy.deepcopy(self.test_instance) test_instance["display_name"] = "purple tomVatoes" test_instance['system_metadata']['owner_project_name'] = 'sweetshop' test_instance['system_metadata']['owner_user_name'] = 'cupcake' ctxt = context.RequestContext(project_id=123, project_name="aubergine", user_id=456, user_name="pie") extra_specs = { "traits:HW_CPU_AMD_SEV": "required", } flavor = objects.Flavor(name='m1.small', memory_mb=6, vcpus=28, root_gb=496, ephemeral_gb=8128, swap=33550336, extra_specs=extra_specs) instance_ref = objects.Instance(**test_instance) instance_ref.flavor = flavor image_meta = objects.ImageMeta.from_dict(self.test_image_meta) disk_info = blockinfo.get_disk_info(CONF.libvirt.virt_type, instance_ref, image_meta) cfg = drvr._get_guest_config(instance_ref, _fake_network_info(self, 1), image_meta, disk_info, context=ctxt) # sev-related tag and memtune should be set self.assertIsInstance(cfg.launch_security, vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestSEVLaunchSecurity) self.assertIsInstance(cfg.memtune, vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestMemoryTune) # all disks are expected to be virtio, thus iommu should be on self.assertTrue(cfg.devices[0].driver_iommu) self.assertTrue(cfg.devices[1].driver_iommu) self.assertTrue(cfg.devices[2].driver_iommu) # controller virtio too self.assertTrue(cfg.devices[3].driver_iommu) # memballoon self.assertTrue(cfg.devices[9].driver_iommu)

commit_message:
monasca-persister: Fix summary - add SUSE rc symlinks

- The summary was too long for rpmlint
- openSUSE likes to have rc$service links. Add theses.

Change-Id: I5300e294c825e9e5b0f29f80ee866a92aa66b156
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rpm-packaging refs/changes/92/681392/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Summary: Persists state transistions in databaseSummary: Persists state transistions in database# install symlinks on SUSE %if 0%{?suse_version} mkdir -p %{buildroot}%{_sbindir} ln -s %{_sbindir}/service %{buildroot}%{_sbindir}/rc%{name} %endif %if 0%{?suse_version} %{_sbindir}/rc%{name} %endif
deleted_lines: Summary: Consumes metrics and alarm state transitions from message queue and stores them in databaseSummary: Consumes metrics and alarm state transitions from message queue and stores them in database

commit_message:
Removing v1 api support

The v1 has officially been removed from Designate since
the Queens release, and was deperecated long before that.

Change-Id: Ic5b44761ff939e2b319924af87849b3a79f9cb07

subject: Update Spec: Add support for VNF packages
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-09-11 10:20:32.000000000', 'files': ['specs/train/vnf_package_support.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker-specs/commit/9d49328382175001a666b0bd1805f0d05921bdc0', 'message': 'Update Spec: Add support for VNF packages

The node template name of type tosca.nodes.nfv.Vdu.Compute fulfills the
purpose of the "SwImageDescId" attribute of the SwImageDesc information
element in ETSI GS NFV-IFA 011 [1] and hence it will be used in APIs to
identify the software image id from the VNFD perspective.
Please refer to clauses  6.8.3.7 and 6.8.4.7 of ETSI GS NFV-SOL 001 V2.6.1 [1].
During processing of vnf package, we can read the software images and
set software_image_id with the name of the node template name.

For example:
    VDU1:
      type: tosca.nodes.nfv.Vdu.Compute
      properties:
        name: my_vdu1
        description: VDU1 compute node
        vdu_profile:
          min_number_of_instances: 1
          max_number_of_instances: 1
        sw_image_data:
          name: Software of VDU1
          version: '0.4.0'
          checksum:
            algorithm: sha-256
            hash: b9c3036539fd7a5f87a1bf38eb05fdde8b556a
          container_format: bare
          disk_format: qcow2
          min_disk: 1 GB
          size: 1 GB

In this case, software_image_id will be set to VDU1.

A VNF can contain multiple deployment flavours and when VNF will be
instantiated, flavour will be passed in the request.
Added `vnf_deployment_flavors` db table so that we can validate the request
directly from the information stored in the db table instead of parsing CSAR
file again and again. Also, changed the column names from 'flavor*' to
'flavour*'.

[1] : https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_gs/NFV-SOL/001_099/001/02.06.01_60/gs_NFV-SOL001v020601p.pdf

Change-Id: I224d7f8f549f7fa1b86245c1275228670d3ed6ad
Blueprint: tosca-csar-mgmt-driver
'}]
commit_message:
Update Spec: Add support for VNF packages

The node template name of type tosca.nodes.nfv.Vdu.Compute fulfills the
purpose of the "SwImageDescId" attribute of the SwImageDesc information
element in ETSI GS NFV-IFA 011 [1] and hence it will be used in APIs to
identify the software image id from the VNFD perspective.
Please refer to clauses  6.8.3.7 and 6.8.4.7 of ETSI GS NFV-SOL 001 V2.6.1 [1].
During processing of vnf package, we can read the software images and
set software_image_id with the name of the node template name.

For example:
    VDU1:
      type: tosca.nodes.nfv.Vdu.Compute
      properties:
        name: my_vdu1
        description: VDU1 compute node
        vdu_profile:
          min_number_of_instances: 1
          max_number_of_instances: 1
        sw_image_data:
          name: Software of VDU1
          version: '0.4.0'
          checksum:
            algorithm: sha-256
            hash: b9c3036539fd7a5f87a1bf38eb05fdde8b556a
          container_format: bare
          disk_format: qcow2
          min_disk: 1 GB
          size: 1 GB
      artifacts:
        sw_image:
          type: tosca.artifacts.nfv.SwImage
          file: Files/images/cirros-0.4.0-x86_64-disk.img

In this case, software_image_id will be set to VDU1.

A VNF can contain multiple deployment flavours and when VNF will be
instantiated, flavour will be passed in the request.
Added `vnf_deployment_flavors` db table so that we can validate the request
directly from the information stored in the db table instead of parsing CSAR
file again and again. Also, changed the column names from 'flavor*' to
'flavour*'.

[1] : https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_gs/NFV-SOL/001_099/001/02.06.01_60/gs_NFV-SOL001v020601p.pdf

Change-Id: I224d7f8f549f7fa1b86245c1275228670d3ed6ad
Blueprint: tosca-csar-mgmt-driver
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker-specs refs/changes/30/681430/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: `updated_at` datetime NULL This table will have `id` as primary key. `updated_at` datetime NULL key of `vnf_packages`.`id`. `vnfd_id` varchar(36) Unique, NULL `updated_at` datetime NULL key of `vnf_packages`.`id`. to read that particular information from the VNF Package file vnf_deployment_flavours:: `id` varchar(36) Pri, NOT NULL `flavour_id` varchar(255) NOT NULL `flavour_description` text NOT NULL `flavour_instantiation_levels` text NULL `created_at` datetime NOT NULL `updated_at` datetime NULL `deleted_at` datetime NULL `deleted` tinyint(1) NULL This table will have `id` as primary key. `package_uuid` will be foreign key of `vnf_packages`.`id`. vnf_software_images:: `id` varchar(36) Pri, NOT NULL `software_image_id` varchar(255) NOT NULL # VDU Name `flavour_uuid` varchar(36) NOT NULL `updated_at` datetime NULL This table will have `id` as primary key. `flavour_uuid` will be foreign key of `vnf_deployment_flavours`.`id`. `updated_at` datetime NULL key of `vnf_software_images.`id`. Upgrade tacker Database to 9d425296f2c3 version ------------------------------------------------ .. code-block:: console tacker-db-manage --config-file /etc/tacker/tacker.conf upgrade 9d425296f2c3 .. REST API impact =============== Below new RestFul APIs will be added:- +-------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+-------------+----------------------------------------+--------------------------+ | Resource name | Resource URI | HTTP Method | Meaning | Response Codes | +=========================+=====================================================+=============+========================================+==========================+ | VNF packages | /vnfpkgm/v1/vnf_packages | GET | Query VNF packages information | Success: 200 | | | | | | Error: 401, 403 | | | +-------------+----------------------------------------+--------------------------+ | | | POST | Create a new individual VNF package | Success: 201 | | | | | resource | Error: 400, 401, 403 | +-------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+-------------+----------------------------------------+--------------------------+ | Individual VNF package | /vnfpkgm/v1/vnf_packages/{vnfPkgId} | GET | Read information about an individual | Success: 200 | | | | | VNF package | Error: 401, 403, 404 | | | +-------------+----------------------------------------+--------------------------+ | | | DELETE | Delete an individual VNF package | Success: 204 | | | | | | Error: 401, 302,404 | +-------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+-------------+----------------------------------------+--------------------------+ | VNF package content | /vnfpkgm/v1/vnf_packages/{vnfPkgId}/package_content | PUT | Upload a VNF package by providing | Success: 202 | | | | | the content of the VNF package | Error: 401, 403, 404, 409| +-------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+-------------+----------------------------------------+--------------------------+ | Upload VNF package from | /vnfpkgm/v1/vnf_packages/{vnfPkgId}/package_content | POST | Upload a VNF package by providing the | Success: 202 | | URI task | /upload_from_uri | | address information of the VNF package | Error: 401, 403, 404, 409| +-------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+-------------+----------------------------------------+--------------------------+ Other end user impact ===================== Below new OpenStackClient commands will be added for managing VNF packages. .. code-block:: console openstack vnf package create openstack vnf package list openstack vnf package show openstack vnf package upload openstack vnf package delete .. Other deployer impact ===================== Changes in api-paste.ini ------------------------ .. code-block:: ini [composite:tacker] /vnfpkgm/v1: vnfpkgmapi_v1 [composite:vnfpkgmapi_v1] use = call:tacker.auth:pipeline_factory noauth = request_id catch_errors extensions vnfpkgmapp_v1 keystone = request_id catch_errors authtoken keystonecontext extensions vnfpkgmapp_v1 [app:vnfpkgmapp_v1] paste.app_factory = tacker.api.vnfpkgm.v1.router:VnfpkgmAPIRouter.factory .. Changes in tacker.conf ----------------------- .. code-block:: console [DEFAULT] vnf_package_delete_interval = 1800 [vnf_package] vnf_package_csar_path = /var/lib/tacker/vnfpackages/ [glance_store] default_backend = file filesystem_store_datadir = /var/lib/tacker/csar_files .. Changes in policy.json ---------------------- Below default policies will be added for the newly added restFul APIs. If you want to customize these policies, you must edit policy.json file. .. code-block:: console # Creates a vnf package. # POST /vnf_packages # "os_nfv_orchestration_api:vnf_packages:create": "rule:admin_or_owner" # Show a vnf package. # GET /vnf_packages/{vnf_package_id} # "os_nfv_orchestration_api:vnf_packages:show": "rule:admin_or_owner" # List all vnf packages. # GET /vnf_packages/ # "os_nfv_orchestration_api:vnf_packages:index": "rule:admin_or_owner" # Delete a vnf package. # DELETE /vnf_packages/{vnf_package_id} # "os_nfv_orchestration_api:vnf_packages:delete": "rule:admin_or_owner" # upload a vnf package content. # PUT /vnf_packages/{vnf_package_id}/package_content # "os_nfv_orchestration_api:vnf_packages:upload_package_content": "rule:admin_or_owner" # upload a vnf package content from uri. # POST /vnf_packages/{vnf_package_id}/package_content/upload_from_uri # "os_nfv_orchestration_api:vnf_packages:upload_from_uri": "rule:admin_or_owner" ..

commit_message:
Set uwsgi to be runned under the same interpreter

In order to run service under the same interpreter across all services
both wsgi and non-wsgi, we need to pass uwsgi_python_executable
while importing uwsgi role.

Change-Id: I942931b85275df2aefca16cce19fcbcac1b43a82

commit_message:
Move to using octavia-lib constants

Previously the samlple data models and driver agent tests used
strings for some of the tests. This patch corrects those to use
constants from octavia-lib.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673681/
Change-Id: I90c2fa386fab75742d07e89edd3fba8b56bb6aff

added_lines: ref_listeners = copy.deepcopy(self.sample_data.provider_listeners) # TODO(johnsom) Remove this once the listener ACLs patch merges # https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659626/ for listener in ref_listeners: del listener.allowed_cidrs 'listeners': ref_listeners, ref_listeners = copy.deepcopy(self.sample_data.provider_listeners) # TODO(johnsom) Remove this once the listener ACLs patch merges # https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659626/ for listener in ref_listeners: del listener.allowed_cidrs self.assertEqual(ref_listeners, provider_listeners) # TODO(johnsom) Remove this once the listener ACLs patch merges # https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659626/ del expect_prov['allowed_cidrs']

commit_message:
Set uwsgi to be runned under the same interpreter

In order to run service under the same interpreter across all services
both wsgi and non-wsgi, we need to pass uwsgi_python_executable
while importing uwsgi role.

Change-Id: If5b6dfc2a750ccc20ae078b46d8be855fe612d91
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_placement refs/changes/20/681420/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: uwsgi_python_executable: "{{ placement_venv_python_executable }}"

commit_message:
Support to create public trove instance

- The users need to specify the network to create Trove instance, but
  trove-taskmanager will create port in that network for Nova instance
  creation. Using port gives Trove more capabilities to define how the
  database service is exposed.
- Deprecate ICMP protocol for the instance.
- Restrict 'nics' parameter for creating instance.
- Add 'access' parameter for creating instance.
- Add 'public_network_id' option in order to create floating IP for the
  instance.
- Do not create records for security groups, but Trove can still delete
  existing instances for backward compatibility.
- Delete unreasonable Host, Account, Storage API.

Story: 2006500
Task: 36468
Task: 36466
Change-Id: I80827e1ad5e6b130cbf94c2bb7a909c44d5cf1e5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/74/680374/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: nics = body['instance'].get('nics', []) if len(nics) > 1: message = "Only one user defined network is supported." raise exception.BadRequest(message=message)

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-09-04 09:48:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/c4b0159103984667d6ac37822bdbe57a0645c208', 'message': 'Correctly set OS_TEST_TIMEOUT in the multinode CI job

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2019-09-10 14:24:27.000000000', 'files': ['zuul.d/ironic-jobs.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/a2febfa6b1a7107c92dd40423ba309398884a338', 'message': 'Correctly set OS_TEST_TIMEOUT in the multinode CI job

DevStack variables do not affect how tox (and thus tempest) is run.

Also reduce the disk size since with 7 VMs we sometimes run out

Change-Id: I7ed6519a700b9bc9a215034b7ac9582f59ec85b5
'}]
commit_message:
Correctly set OS_TEST_TIMEOUT in the multinode CI job

DevStack variables do not affect how tox (and thus tempest) is run.

Also reduce the disk size since with 7 VMs we sometimes run out
of disk space on testing nodes.

Change-Id: I7ed6519a700b9bc9a215034b7ac9582f59ec85b5

commit_message:
glance: Simplify stestr run command

We don't need a SUSE/RDO condition for calling stestr.

Change-Id: I5105b3c8c687625601d1dfb56b828d842426354a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rpm-packaging refs/changes/89/681389/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: PYTHONPATH=. python3 -m stestr.cli --test-path glance/tests/unit run
deleted_lines: %if 0%{?suse_version} PYTHON=python3 OS_TEST_PATH=./glance/tests/unit PYTHONPATH=. stestr run %endif %if 0%{?rdo} OS_TEST_PATH=./glance/tests/unit PYTHONPATH=. stestr-3 run %endif

commit_message:
Decrypt Ceph keyring files using ansible-vault

This commit allows Ceph keyrings to be decrypted using
ansible-vault.

Change-Id: I0c841f40782480e405b1cbb4a5627b900e625f69
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/41/676441/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- security: - | Keyring files for Cinder and Glance can be encrypted using Ansible-Vault and stored in the 'node_custom_config' path when using an external Ceph cluster.

subject: Enable booting of libvirt guests with AMD SEV memory encryption
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-06-20 15:43:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/240086f07f1793ad6a500678f6646acc83d5ddf2', 'message': 'Track inventory for new MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT resource class

Track compute node inventory for the new MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
resource class (added in os-resource-classes 0.4.0) which represents
the number of guests a compute node can host concurrently with memory
encrypted at the hardware level.

Initially this is required because on AMD SEV-capable hardware, the
memory controller has a fixed number of slots for holding encryption
keys, one per guest.  Typical early hardware only has 15 slots,
thereby limiting the number of SEV guests which can be run
concurrently to 15.  nova needs to track how many slots are available
and used in order to avoid attempting to exceeding that limit in the
hardware.

Work is in progress to allow QEMU and libvirt to expose the number of
slots available on SEV hardware; however until this is finished and
released, it will not be possible for nova to programatically detect
the correct value with which to populate the MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
inventory.  So as a stop-gap, populate the inventory using the value
manually provided by the cloud operator in the
CONF.libvirt.num_memory_encrypted_guests configuration option, which
was added previously.

Change-Id: I659cb77f12a38a4d2fb118530ebb9de88d2ed30d
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2019-06-20 20:39:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7c3d33ac67011a21f2a284762a47b01fe026fe0d', 'message': 'Enable booting of libvirt guests with AMD SEV memory encryption

Track compute node inventory for the new MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
resource class (added in os-resource-classes 0.4.0) which represents
the number of guests a compute node can host concurrently with memory
encrypted at the hardware level.

This serves as a "master switch" for enabling SEV functionality, since
all the code which takes advantage of the presence of this inventory
in order to boot SEV-enabled guests is already in place, but none of
it gets used until the inventory is non-zero.

A discrete inventory is required because on AMD SEV-capable hardware,
the memory controller has a fixed number of slots for holding
encryption keys, one per guest.  Typical early hardware only has 15
slots, thereby limiting the number of SEV guests which can be run
concurrently to 15.  nova needs to track how many slots are available
and used in order to avoid attempting to exceeding that limit in the
hardware.

Work is in progress to allow QEMU and libvirt to expose the number of
slots available on SEV hardware; however until this is finished and
released, it will not be possible for nova to programatically detect
the correct value with which to populate the MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
inventory.  So as a stop-gap, populate the inventory using the value
manually provided by the cloud operator in a new configuration option
CONF.libvirt.num_memory_encrypted_guests.

Since this commit effectively enables SEV, also add all the relevant
documentation as planned in the AMD SEV spec[0]:

- Add operation.boot-encrypted-vm to the KVM hypervisor feature matrix.

- Update the KVM section of the Configuration Guide.

- Add a release note.

[0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.html#documentation-impact

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: I659cb77f12a38a4d2fb118530ebb9de88d2ed30d

- Add operation.boot-encrypted-vm to the KVM hypervisor feature matrix.

'}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2019-07-24 10:59:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/056519e5126647d528fd74d591f3f395ca822ded', 'message': 'Enable booting of libvirt guests with AMD SEV memory encryption

Track compute node inventory for the new MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
resource class (added in os-resource-classes 0.4.0) which represents
the number of guests a compute node can host concurrently with memory
encrypted at the hardware level.

This serves as a "master switch" for enabling SEV functionality, since
all the code which takes advantage of the presence of this inventory
in order to boot SEV-enabled guests is already in place, but none of
it gets used until the inventory is non-zero.

A discrete inventory is required because on AMD SEV-capable hardware,
the memory controller has a fixed number of slots for holding
encryption keys, one per guest.  Typical early hardware only has 15
slots, thereby limiting the number of SEV guests which can be run
concurrently to 15.  nova needs to track how many slots are available
and used in order to avoid attempting to exceeding that limit in the
hardware.

Work is in progress to allow QEMU and libvirt to expose the number of
slots available on SEV hardware; however until this is finished and
released, it will not be possible for nova to programatically detect
the correct value with which to populate the MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
inventory.  So as a stop-gap, populate the inventory using the value
manually provided by the cloud operator in a new configuration option
CONF.libvirt.num_memory_encrypted_guests.

Since this commit effectively enables SEV, also add all the relevant
documentation as planned in the AMD SEV spec[0]:

- Add operation.boot-encrypted-vm to the KVM hypervisor feature matrix.

- Update the KVM section of the Configuration Guide.

- Add a release note.

[0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.html#documentation-impact

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: I659cb77f12a38a4d2fb118530ebb9de88d2ed30d

it gets used until the inventory is non-zero.

A discrete inventory is required because on AMD SEV-capable hardware,
the memory controller has a fixed number of slots for holding
encryption keys, one per guest.  Typical early hardware only has 15
slots, thereby limiting the number of SEV guests which can be run
concurrently to 15.  nova needs to track how many slots are available
and used in order to avoid attempting to exceeding that limit in the
hardware.

Work is in progress to allow QEMU and libvirt to expose the number of
slots available on SEV hardware; however until this is finished and
released, it will not be possible for nova to programatically detect
the correct value with which to populate the MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
inventory.  So as a stop-gap, populate the inventory using the value
manually provided by the cloud operator in a new configuration option
CONF.libvirt.num_memory_encrypted_guests.

Since this commit effectively enables SEV, also add all the relevant
documentation as planned in the AMD SEV spec[0]:

- Add operation.boot-encrypted-vm to the KVM hypervisor feature matrix.

- Update the KVM section of the Configuration Guide.

- Add a release note.

[0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.html#documentation-impact

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: I659cb77f12a38a4d2fb118530ebb9de88d2ed30d

'}, {'number': 38, 'created': '2019-08-29 20:38:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5ae6d9b84f7ebc4deeae4733ed6eaf5557ef9b54', 'message': 'Enable booting of libvirt guests with AMD SEV memory encryption

Track compute node inventory for the new MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
resource class (added in os-resource-classes 0.4.0) which represents
the number of guests a compute node can host concurrently with memory
encrypted at the hardware level.

This serves as a "master switch" for enabling SEV functionality, since
all the code which takes advantage of the presence of this inventory
in order to boot SEV-enabled guests is already in place, but none of
it gets used until the inventory is non-zero.

A discrete inventory is required because on AMD SEV-capable hardware,
the memory controller has a fixed number of slots for holding
encryption keys, one per guest.  Typical early hardware only has 15
slots, thereby limiting the number of SEV guests which can be run
concurrently to 15.  nova needs to track how many slots are available
and used in order to avoid attempting to exceed that limit in the
hardware.

Work is in progress to allow QEMU and libvirt to expose the number of
slots available on SEV hardware; however until this is finished and
released, it will not be possible for nova to programatically detect
the correct value with which to populate the MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
inventory.  So as a stop-gap, populate the inventory using the value
manually provided by the cloud operator in a new configuration option
CONF.libvirt.num_memory_encrypted_guests.

Since this commit effectively enables SEV, also add all the relevant
documentation as planned in the AMD SEV spec[0]:

- Add operation.boot-encrypted-vm to the KVM hypervisor feature matrix.

- Update the KVM section of the Configuration Guide.

- Update the flavors section of the User Guide.

- Add a release note.

[0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.html#documentation-impact

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: I659cb77f12a38a4d2fb118530ebb9de88d2ed30d

resource class (added in os-resource-classes 0.4.0) which represents
the number of guests a compute node can host concurrently with memory
encrypted at the hardware level.

This serves as a "master switch" for enabling SEV functionality, since
all the code which takes advantage of the presence of this inventory
in order to boot SEV-enabled guests is already in place, but none of
it gets used until the inventory is non-zero.

A discrete inventory is required because on AMD SEV-capable hardware,
the memory controller has a fixed number of slots for holding
encryption keys, one per guest.  Typical early hardware only has 15
slots, thereby limiting the number of SEV guests which can be run
concurrently to 15.  nova needs to track how many slots are available
and used in order to avoid attempting to exceed that limit in the
hardware.

Work is in progress to allow QEMU and libvirt to expose the number of
slots available on SEV hardware; however until this is finished and
released, it will not be possible for nova to programatically detect
the correct value with which to populate the MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
inventory.  So as a stop-gap, populate the inventory using the value
manually provided by the cloud operator in a new configuration option
CONF.libvirt.num_memory_encrypted_guests.

Since this commit effectively enables SEV, also add all the relevant
documentation as planned in the AMD SEV spec[0]:

- Add operation.boot-encrypted-vm to the KVM hypervisor feature matrix.

- Update the KVM section of the Configuration Guide.

- Update the flavors section of the User Guide.

- Add a release note.

[0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.html#documentation-impact

commit_message:
Enable booting of libvirt guests with AMD SEV memory encryption

Track compute node inventory for the new MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
resource class (added in os-resource-classes 0.4.0) which represents
the number of guests a compute node can host concurrently with memory
encrypted at the hardware level.

This serves as a "master switch" for enabling SEV functionality, since
all the code which takes advantage of the presence of this inventory
in order to boot SEV-enabled guests is already in place, but none of
it gets used until the inventory is non-zero.

A discrete inventory is required because on AMD SEV-capable hardware,
the memory controller has a fixed number of slots for holding
encryption keys, one per guest.  Typical early hardware only has 15
slots, thereby limiting the number of SEV guests which can be run
concurrently to 15.  nova needs to track how many slots are available
and used in order to avoid attempting to exceed that limit in the
hardware.

Work is in progress to allow QEMU and libvirt to expose the number of
slots available on SEV hardware; however until this is finished and
released, it will not be possible for nova to programatically detect
the correct value with which to populate the MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT
inventory.  So as a stop-gap, populate the inventory using the value
manually provided by the cloud operator in a new configuration option
CONF.libvirt.num_memory_encrypted_guests.

Since this commit effectively enables SEV, also add all the relevant
documentation as planned in the AMD SEV spec[0]:

- Add operation.boot-encrypted-vm to the KVM hypervisor feature matrix.

- Update the KVM section of the Configuration Guide.

- Update the flavors section of the User Guide.

- Add a release note.

[0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.html#documentation-impact

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: I659cb77f12a38a4d2fb118530ebb9de88d2ed30d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/16/666616/47 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os_resource_classes as orcfrom nova.db import constants as db_const def assertMemEncryptionSlotsEqual(self, slots): inventory = self._get_provider_inventory(self.host_uuid) if slots == 0: self.assertNotIn(orc.MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT, inventory) else: self.assertEqual( inventory[orc.MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT], { 'total': slots, 'min_unit': 1, 'max_unit': slots, 'step_size': 1, 'allocation_ratio': 1.0, 'reserved': 0, } ) Also test that on both occasions, the inventory of the MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT resource class on the compute host corresponds to the absence or presence of the SEV capability. self.assertMemEncryptionSlotsEqual(0) self.assertMemEncryptionSlotsEqual(db_const.MAX_INT) def pre_start_compute(self): super(LibvirtReportSevTraitsTests, self).pre_start_compute() self.flags(num_memory_encrypted_guests=16, group='libvirt') Also test that on both occasions, the inventory of the MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT resource class on the compute host corresponds to the absence or presence of the SEV capability. self.assertMemEncryptionSlotsEqual(16) self.assertMemEncryptionSlotsEqual(0)

commit_message:
Fix python3 compatibility of rbd get_fsid

In python3 librados's get_fsid() function is represented as binary.
This causes problems with nova rbd driver as we rely on get_fsid
return value, which should be string, not bytes.
Same fix is in cinder ang glance_store until librados will
be fixed.

Change-Id: Icbb0b341be19f87bd23064a2b4f98e68bf492a25

commit_message:
Get resource provider by uuid or name

This patch updates openstack resource provider (show|set|delete)
commands such way either RP uuid or RP name could be specified
as RP identifier.

Change-Id: I864920425b7ef27cb8dffc32d673059b56748661
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/osc-placement refs/changes/91/527791/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from uuid import UUID URLS = { 'resource_providers': '/resource_providers' } def is_valid_uuid(uuid_to_test, version=4): try: uuid_obj = UUID(uuid_to_test, version=version) except: return False return str(uuid_obj) == uuid_to_test def get_rp_uuid(http, uuid_or_name): if is_valid_uuid(uuid_or_name): return uuid_or_name else: resources = http.request( 'GET', '{}?name={}'.format( URLS['resource_providers'], uuid_or_name) ).json()['resource_providers'] if len(resources) != 1: raise ValueError('Cannot find resource provider by name') return resources[0]['uuid']

commit_message:
Run only smoke tests in ipv6 job

'congress-tempest-ipv6-only' job is to verify
that congress is able to listen and run on IPv6
env. We do not need to run all the tests in this
job. Running only smoke tests should be fine.

This commit define the 'congress-ipv6' tox env which
include smoke test only as of now but it can be extended
to include more IPv6 tests if any.

Change-Id: Idbd4c6ea362487dd93330adddb26abc89387a726
Story: #2005477
Task: #35885
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/57/676857/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:congress-ipv6] envdir = .tox/tempest sitepackages = True setenv = {[tempestenv]setenv} deps = {[tempestenv]deps} # The regex below is used to select the congress smoke tests only. In future, # it can be extended to include more IPv6 related tests. commands = find . -type f -name "*.pyc" -delete tempest run --list-tests --regex '(^congress_tempest_plugin.*)(\[.*\bsmoke\b.*\])' {posargs}

commit_message:
Reject live migration and suspend on SEV guests

As per the spec[0], live migration and suspend are not (yet) supported
for SEV guests, so reject them at the API level with an HTTP
409 (Conflict).

[0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.html#limitations

blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support
Change-Id: I69b6e153324a3e5680e096cd714e5d4dd05bae34
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/58/680158/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch('nova.virt.hardware.get_mem_encryption_constraint', new=mock.Mock(return_value=True)) def test_live_migrate_sev_rejected(self): instance = self._stub_instance_get() body = {'os-migrateLive': {'host': 'hostname', 'block_migration': 'auto'}} ex = self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPConflict, self.controller._migrate_live, self.req, fakes.FAKE_UUID, body=body) self.assertIn('Operation live_migrate not supported for SEV-enabled ' 'instance (%s)' % instance.uuid, six.text_type(ex))

commit_message:
Add Huawei Ascend driver

This patch adds the Huawei Ascend driver.

Change-Id: I105f34de9ad95db2e98ac41836e686bafda6c0a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cyborg refs/changes/74/660874/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cyborg.accelerator.drivers.driver import GenericDriver from cyborg.objects.driver_objects import driver_deployable, driver_device, \ driver_attach_handle, driver_controlpath_id import re import subprocess from cyborg.common import constants from oslo_serialization import jsonutils PCI_INFO_PATTERN = re.compile("(?P<slot>[0-9a-f]{4}:[0-9a-f]{2}:" "[0-9a-f]{2}\.[0-9a-f]) " "(?P<class>.*) [\[].*]: (?P<device>.*) .*" "[\[](?P<vendor_id>[0-9a-fA-F]" "{4}):(?P<device_id>[0-9a-fA-F]{4})].*" "[(rev ](?P<revision>[0-9a-f]{2})") class AscendDriver(GenericDriver): """Base class for GPU drivers. This is just a virtual GPU drivers interface. Vendor should implement their specific drivers. """ VENDOR = "huawei" # TODO(yikun): can be extracted into PCIDeviceDriver def _generate_controlpath_id(self, pci): driver_cpid = driver_controlpath_id.DriverControlPathID() driver_cpid.cpid_type = "PCI" driver_cpid.cpid_info = pci["slot"] return driver_cpid # TODO(yikun): can be extracted into PCIDeviceDriver def _generate_attach_handle(self, pci): driver_ah = driver_attach_handle.DriverAttachHandle() driver_ah.attach_type = "PCI" driver_ah.in_use = False driver_ah.attach_info = pci["slot"] return driver_ah # TODO(yikun): can be extracted into PCIDeviceDriver def _generate_dep_list(self, pci): driver_dep = driver_deployable.DriverDeployable() driver_dep.attach_handle_list = [self._generate_attach_handle(pci)] driver_dep.name = pci.get('device', '') + '_' + pci["slot"] driver_dep.num_accelerators = 1 return [driver_dep] # TODO(yikun): can be extracted into PCIDeviceDriver def _get_pci_lines(self, keywords=()): cmd = "sudo lspci -nnn -D" if keywords: cmd += "| grep -E %s" % '|'.join(keywords) p = subprocess.Popen(cmd, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, shell=True) p.wait() pci_lines = p.stdout.readlines() return pci_lines def discover(self): """ The PCI line would be matchde as: 0000:0c:00.0 Processing accelerators [1200]: Device [19e5:d100] (rev 20) { 'slot': '0000:0c:00.0', # domain:bus:device.function 'device': 'Device', # Name of the device 'vendor_id': '19e5', # ID of the vendor 'class': 'Processing accelerators', # Name of the class 'device_id': 'd100', # ID of the device 'revision': '20' # Revision number } """ ascends = self._get_pci_lines(('d100',)) npu_list = [] for ascend in ascends: m = PCI_INFO_PATTERN.match(ascend) if m: pci_dict = m.groupdict() device = driver_device.DriverDevice() device.vendor = pci_dict["vendor_id"] device.model = pci_dict.get('model', 'miss model info') std_board_info = {'device_id': pci_dict.get('device_id', None), 'class': pci_dict.get('class', None)} device.std_board_info = jsonutils.dumps(std_board_info) device.type = constants.DEVICE_NPU device.controlpath_id = self._generate_controlpath_id(pci_dict) device.deployable_list = self._generate_dep_list(pci_dict) npu_list.append(device) return npu_list def update(self, control_path, image_path): # TODO(yikun): To be implemented return True def get_stats(self): # TODO(yikun): To be implemented return {}

commit_message:
Sync Sphinx requirement

Sync sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.

commit_message:
Store virtual media device changes persistently

Prior to this patch, ejecting virtual media was not communicated
to libvirt effectively  leaving virtual media inserted.

Also, changing virtual media properties has not been stored
persistently in the emulator.

Co-Authored-By: Ilya Etingof <etingof@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ib5505c9a5dbd55bba81bcd6bd5ba315e944e8896

deleted_lines: {(identity, k): v for k, v in self._device_types.items()})

commit_message:
Clean up app initialization and config

* Remove unnecessary code in OpenStackShell.initialize_app() - only
  the bits it instantiate our subclass of ClientManager remain
* Remove OSC_Config - with https://review.opendev.org/#/c/678095/
  the last remaining required bit moves to osc-lib

Thos requires osc-lib 1.14.0

Change-Id: Ia4b3c737de9dc34949e74632441621014ef9eea9
Signed-off-by: Dean Troyer <dtroyer@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/46/678146/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Re-create the client_manager with our subclass
deleted_lines: from openstackclient.common import client_config as cloud_config # Argument precedence is really broken in multiple places # so we're just going to fix it here until o-c-c and osc-lib # get sorted out. # TODO(dtroyer): remove when os-client-config and osc-lib are fixed # First, throw away what has already been done with o-c-c and # use our own. try: self.cloud_config = cloud_config.OSC_Config( override_defaults={ 'interface': None, 'auth_type': self._auth_type, }, ) except (IOError, OSError): self.log.critical("Could not read clouds.yaml configuration file") self.print_help_if_requested() raise if not self.options.debug: self.options.debug = None # NOTE(dtroyer): Need to do this with validate=False to defer the # auth plugin handling to ClientManager.setup_auth() self.cloud = self.cloud_config.get_one_cloud( cloud=self.options.cloud, argparse=self.options, validate=False, ) # Then, re-create the client_manager with the correct arguments

commit_message:
Use created subnet in port generator in "test_port_ip_update_revises"

We are hitting sometimes a problem in "test_port_ip_update_revises" [1].
This happens because the port created doesn't belong to the previously
created subnet. We need to enforce that the port is created in the
subnet specifically created in this test.

[1]http://logs.openstack.org/69/650269/12/check/openstack-tox-lower-constraints/7adf36e/testr_results.html.gz

Conflicts:
    neutron/tests/unit/services/revisions/test_revision_plugin.py

Change-Id: I399f100fe30b6a03248cef5e6026204d4d1ffb2e
Closes-Bug: #1828865
(cherry picked from commit 872dd7f48400f0ee059876b01d4034aa75f97787)

commit_message:
Add db api tests for scheduled jobs

Change-Id: I803fa8724298d6d79f14cd4d6b67eeba05b9a529
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/59/669559/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: SCHEDULED_JOBS = [ { 'run_after': 30, 'func_name': 'test_module.test_func', 'func_args': { 'server': 'localhost', 'database': 'test', 'timeout': 600, 'verbose': True }, 'execute_at': datetime.datetime(2019, 7, 6, 15, 1, 0) }, { 'run_after': 50, 'target_factory_func_name': 'test_target_factory_func', 'func_name': 'test_func', 'func_args': { 'server': 'localhost', 'database': 'test', 'timeout': 600, 'verbose': True }, 'execute_at': datetime.datetime(2019, 7, 6, 20, 30, 0) }, ] class ScheduledJobTest(SQLAlchemyTest): def setUp(self): super(ScheduledJobTest, self).setUp() db_api.delete_scheduled_jobs() def test_create_and_get_scheduled_job(self): created = db_api.create_scheduled_job(SCHEDULED_JOBS[0]) fetched = db_api.get_scheduled_job(created.id) self.assertEqual(created, fetched) def test_create_scheduled_job_duplicate_without_auth(self): cfg.CONF.set_default('auth_enable', False, group='pecan') db_api.create_scheduled_job(SCHEDULED_JOBS[0]) db_api.create_scheduled_job(SCHEDULED_JOBS[0]) def test_update_scheduled_job(self): created = db_api.create_scheduled_job(SCHEDULED_JOBS[0]) self.assertIsNone(created.updated_at) updated = db_api.update_scheduled_job( created.id, {'captured_at': datetime.datetime(2019, 7, 6, 20, 30, 0)} ) self.assertEqual( datetime.datetime(2019, 7, 6, 20, 30, 0), updated[0].captured_at ) fetched = db_api.get_scheduled_job(created.id) self.assertEqual(updated[0], fetched) self.assertIsNotNone(fetched.updated_at) def test_get_scheduled_jobs(self): created0 = db_api.create_scheduled_job(SCHEDULED_JOBS[0]) created1 = db_api.create_scheduled_job(SCHEDULED_JOBS[1]) fetched = db_api.get_scheduled_jobs() self.assertEqual(2, len(fetched)) self._assert_single_item(fetched, func_name=created0['func_name']) self._assert_single_item(fetched, func_name=created1['func_name']) def test_delete_scheduled_job(self): created = db_api.create_scheduled_job(SCHEDULED_JOBS[0]) fetched = db_api.get_scheduled_job(created.id) self.assertEqual(created, fetched) db_api.delete_scheduled_job(created.id) self.assertRaises( exc.DBEntityNotFoundError, db_api.get_environment, created.id ) def test_get_scheduled_jobs_count(self): res = db_api.get_scheduled_jobs_count() self.assertEqual(0, res) created0 = db_api.create_scheduled_job(SCHEDULED_JOBS[0]) created1 = db_api.create_scheduled_job(SCHEDULED_JOBS[1]) res = db_api.get_scheduled_jobs_count() self.assertEqual(2, res) db_api.delete_scheduled_job(created0.id) res = db_api.get_scheduled_jobs_count() self.assertEqual(1, res) db_api.delete_scheduled_job(created1.id) res = db_api.get_scheduled_jobs_count() self.assertEqual(0, res)

commit_message:
trivial: Remove vendored 'is_safe_url' function

This has been present since at least Django 1.6 [1], though the comment
on the removed function suggests it might have been earlier (pre-Git
days, perhaps?).

[1] https://github.com/django/django/commit/a2f2a399566

Change-Id: Ib6978ffa8d3962383fbc0a1c3cfd9da9e162f7dd
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/69/678669/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # From django.contrib.auth.views # Added in Django 1.4.3, 1.5b2 # Vendored here for compatibility with old Django versions. def is_safe_url(url, host=None): """Return ``True`` if the url is a safe redirection. The safe redirection means that it doesn't point to a different host. Always returns ``False`` on an empty url. """ if not url: return False netloc = urlparse.urlparse(url)[1] return not netloc or netloc == host

commit_message:
Bump timeout for lower-constraints job

In ba0dbdf we raised the timeouts for most of the tox jobs but neglected
the lower-constraints job which suffers the same timeout issues, so add
that one as well.

Change-Id: I213d6f91a815ba0dad5f5a04a5f0309722c91f62
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/61/681161/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Generate PDF documentation

This patch adds a new tox job/command for building the pdf
version of documentation.

tox -epdf-docs

In addition to adjusting the infra requirement for PDF build
support, the following changes are made to build a PDF doc

- Download link of config_options, sample config and policy
  files are disabled for PDF doc as relative links do not
  make sense.
- Pre-create the doc/build/pdf/_static directory as a
  workaround because sphinx_feature_classification.support_matrix extension
  is operating under the assumption that the _static directory already exist
  and trying to copy support-matrix.css into it. We need to remove
  this workaround once the problem in the support_matrix extension is fixed.
- Use the toctree_only=True workaround to avoid TOC duplicate links.

Change-Id: Ief8df5f6a5a22b8d0530458ac45f344a72cc3e49
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/82/669982/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: whitelist_externals = make cp sphinx-build -W -b latex doc/source doc/build/pdf make -C doc/build/pdf cp doc/build/pdf/Keystone.pdf doc/build/html/

subject: Fix the race in confirm resize func test
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-09-10 12:12:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5647b280a81fb997c4115c56225c0c3c341d1b81', 'message': 'Shrink the race window in confirm resize func test

New confirm resize functional tests were added in
Ia69dace6d3b395fa113c1382e8eb52c2cc36119d. But they could be racy [1]
because the migration allocation is deleted in placement as the last
thing in the confirm_resize process. So it happens after the migratin is
set to confirmed and the instance state is set to ACTIVE.

This patch shrink the window by waiting for the instance state as it
happens later than the migration status update. However the test still
can race.

[1] https://954d3ddb67e757934983-a9cc155153d08dd30dfffbbf1d71d234.ssl.cf5.rackcdn.com/676138/16/gate/nova-tox-functional-py36/fb5d235/testr_results.html.gz

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2019-09-10 14:57:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/49ead22cb30a8ade77bab9359216f5b34c0dbdb4', 'message': 'Fix the race in confirm resize func test

New confirm resize functional tests were added in
Ia69dace6d3b395fa113c1382e8eb52c2cc36119d. But they could be racy [1]
because the migration allocation is deleted in placement as the last
thing in the confirm_resize process. So it happens after the migration is
set to confirmed and the instance state is set to ACTIVE.

This patch changes the confirm resize tests to wait for the successful
instance action event as that is sent _after_ the migration allocation

commit_message:
Fix the race in confirm resize func test

New confirm resize functional tests were added in
Ia69dace6d3b395fa113c1382e8eb52c2cc36119d. But they could be racy [1]
because the migration allocation is deleted in placement as the last
thing in the confirm_resize process. So it happens after the migration is
set to confirmed and the instance state is set to ACTIVE.

This patch changes the confirm resize tests to wait for the successful
instance action event as that is sent _after_ the migration allocation
is deleted.

[1] see the bug report

Closes-Bug: #1843433

Change-Id: Ibeb16ce16263c43bad9f148480bbebca413d8117
